item.title: User-defined functions in SQLite
item.description: Write functions in plain SQL using the ‘define’ extension. SQLite does not directly support user-defined functions. Sure, one can write a function in C or Python and register it within SQLite. But not in SQL itself. Luckily for us, SQLite provides an extension mechanism. item.title: Expressive Ellipsis in Python
item.description: One of the lesser-known things in Python is the ellipsis: class Flyer: def fly(self): ... This code works. The ... (aka Ellipsis)Â is a real object that can be used in code. Ellipsis is the only instance of the EllipsisType type (similar to how None is the only instance of the NoneType type): >>> ... is Ellipsis >>> True >>> Ellipsis is ... >>> True Python core devs mostly use .

Like selecting a number from a range with a step: random.randrange(10, 99, 3) # 91 Or a random sequence element: numbers = [7, 9, 13, 42, 64, 99] random.choice(numbers) # 42 Or multiple elements: numbers = range(99, 10, -1) random.choices(numbers, k=3) # [32, 62, 76] How about choosing some elements more often than others?

item.title: Temporary tables in SQLite
item.description: Sometimes you want to combine data from multiple tables into one and query the results. For example, join vacancies together with employers and regions: select v.*, e.name, a.name from vacancy as v join employer as e on e.id = v.employer_id join area as a on a.id = v.area_id The question is how to reference the combined dataset in further queries. item.title: JSON and virtual columns in SQLite
item.description: Generated columns have another great use case. Let’s say you decide to keep a log of events that occur in the system. There are different types of events, each with its own set of fields. For example, sign-in: { "timestamp": "2022-05-15T09:31:00Z", "object": "user", "object_id": 11, "action": "login", "details": { "ip": "192.168.0.1" } } Or account deposit: { "timestamp": "2022-05-15T09:32:00Z", "object": "account", "object_id": 12, "action": "deposit", "details": { "amount": "1000", "currency": "USD" } } You decide to store the raw JSON, as normalization is non-trivial.

item.title: Compact objects in Python
